results.abstract: Gen Elec Research and Development Center scientists Drs H R Hart, R L Fleischer and P B Price rept cosmic ray tracks found on Apollo astronauts' helmets indicate that exposure to heavier, more damaging rays might be serious problem for astronauts on future long missions, article in Science (pub); suspect rays are same ones that caused peculiar flashes to appear in astronauts' eyes when closed or during periods of darkness; believe such rays can kill cells in brain, nervous system and retina; rept studies indicate hazard is reduced when sun is at peak of sunspot activity because radiation from sun diverts cosmic rays (W Sullivan rept)

headline.main: RAY PERIL SHOWN BY SPACE HELMET; Scientist Report on Tracks Found in Apollo Gear

results.snippet: Cosmic ray tracks found in helmets worn into space by Apollo astronauts have shown that exposure to the heavier, more damaging rays was sufficient to raise a serious problem on long missions, such as one to Mars.
results.lead_paragraph: Cosmic ray tracks found in helmets worn into space by Apollo astronauts have shown that exposure to the heavier, more damaging rays was sufficient to raise a serious problem on long missions, such as one to Mars.

headline.main: Versatile Crewmen of Soyuz 10; Vladimir A. Shatalov Aleksei S. Yeliseyev Nikolai N. Rukavishnikov

headline.main: Docking Described By Crew of Soyuz; Astronauts Describe Docking of Soyuz

results.snippet: MOSCOW, April 25 -- A crew member of the Soyuz 10 spacecraft, which returned to the earth early this morning, today described the docking of his ship with the unmanned orbita laboratory Salyut as "a little like a train entering a railroad terminal."

headline.main: Shepard and a Negro Named Admirals

results.snippet: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- The Navy announced today the selection of Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr., America's first man in space, as the first astronaut to become an admiral. At the same time, it said that Capt. Samuel L. Gravely Jr., commander of a...
results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- The Navy announced today the selection of Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr., America's first man in space, as the first astronaut to become an admiral. At the same time, it said that Capt. Samuel L. Gravely Jr., commander of a guided missile frigate, would become its first black admiral.
